title: The Story of a Confederate Boy in the Civil War

quoteFirst: Saturday, April 22, at 4:25 a.m., the U.S. steamers Valley City and Whitehead got under weigh, and at 8:30 a.m. arrived at Plymouth, where we anchored. At
quoteLast: , the Valley City and Whitehead got under weigh, and arrived at Edenton at 5:30 p.m., and at 11 p.m. the Valley City and Whitehead got under weigh and steamed toward Hertford, N.C., where we arrived on Sunday, April 23, at 7-1/2 a.m. At 10 a.m. the officers of the two vessels in full uniform went to an Episcopal service held in a church in Hertford.
title: Reminiscences of Two Years in the United States Navy
author: Batten, John M. (John Mullin), 1837-1916

quoteFirst: It's a, fine thing to get started, however late in the day, and though it was

quoteFirst: “There!” said Penrod, returning from performing this errand for the fourth time. “It's
quoteLast: , and I'm not goin' in to look at that ole clock again if I haf to die for it! I never heard anybody make such a fuss in my life, and I'm gettin' tired of it. Must think we want to be all night fixin' this cage for our panther! If you ask me to go and see what time it is again, Herman, I'm a-goin' to take back about askin' mamma at five o'clock, and THEN where'll you be?”
title: Penrod and Sam
author: Tarkington, Booth, 1869-1946

quoteFirst: "Two days after we received the news that a niece of mine had died at
quoteLast: . The children had never known anything of the former appearances, as we had never talked about it before them. We have seen nothing since of the bird, but have for some years had no death in the family.
title: Animal Ghosts; Or, Animal Hauntings and the Hereafter
author: O'Donnell, Elliott, 1872-1965

quoteLast: and the days were getting short, I thought that by rapid climbing I could reach the summit before sunset, in time to get a general view and a few pencil sketches, and make my way back to the steamer in the night. title: Travels in Alaska
author: Muir, John, 1838-1914

quoteFirst: They were exceedingly noisy and merry: they seemed to make the arena-side to flash with their teeth. Until about
quoteLast: , many of them shouted insults at the two whites, who sat unmoved, not knowing the debased dialect of the Occidental. After twenty minutes past three, many white men entered: the insults stopped, a drummer, a zither-player and a bone-rattler struck up a jig to which the negroes kept time with Hues and stamping.
title: Sard Harker: A novel
author: Masefield, John, 1878-1967

quoteFirst: Lawrence was so slowly floating away--we regret to say that the ice-bridge of 1874 was making itself memorable yesterday to Quebec in a shape more formidable than its perverse tenacity or its injurious effects upon trade. It was rioting in a perfect orgie of destruction, crushing man's handwork in its passage like so much frail glass in the grasp of a giant. At
quoteLast: , when the glad announcement passed from mouth to mouth that the ice was moving, it began its destructive work. The scene was at Blais Booms and the immediate neighborhood, where the Government steamers _Napoleon III_ and _Druid_, the Gulf Ports steamers _Georgia_, _Miramichi_ and _Hadji_ and a large number of tug steamers and other craft belonging to the St.
title: Picturesque Quebec : a sequel to Quebec past and present
author: Le Moine, J. M. (James MacPherson), Sir, 1825-1912

quoteFirst: A falling shower had soaked the crowd, but they had not withdrawn a step. Rasseneur's dog had begun to bark again. And it was at
quoteLast: only that the first shock was felt. The Voreux trembled, but continued solid and upright.

quoteFirst: He ascends, puts forward the hands of the clock, but forgets to put the hands and the striking bell in harmony. He rumples up the bed, but he does it awkwardly--and it is impossible to reconcile these three facts, the bed crumpled, the clock showing
quoteLast: , and the countess dressed as if it were mid-day. He adds as much as he can to the disorder of the room. He smears a sheet with blood; also the bed-curtains and furniture.
title: The Mystery of Orcival
author: Gaboriau, Emile, 1832-1873

quoteFirst: The horses had strayed so far in search of green grass that we did not start till 10.30 a.m., when we steered south-east, crossing a spur of the tableland which lay to the south-west; then crossing several valleys and small watercourses trending to the north-east, camped at a shallow waterhole at
quoteLast: The country was of sandstone formation and the soil very poor, melaleuca scrubs prevailing on the lower ground, and eucalypti, acacia, and grevillia on the hills; to the south-west the hills were rocky, with a rounded outline, but to the north-east they were flat-topped and of less height.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888
